s.text: I can't say I recommend it.
I can't say I recommend it.
I can't say I recommend it.
I can't say I recommend it.
The consumer-centric "long boom" of the 1990s seems utterly distant from the dry post-industrial world Bell describes, full of references to Weber, Rousseau, Locke, and Lenin.
Since we live in an Age of Information, I'll "bullet point" them for easier retrieval:

It's similar to Norbert Weiner's thinking (the originator of the term "cybernetics" from the Greek word for "helmsman"), which postulated that society would be increasingly governed by "feedback," allowing elites to steer better.
The consumer-centric "long boom" of the 1990s seems utterly distant from the dry post-industrial world Bell describes, full of references to Weber, Rousseau, Locke, and Lenin.
Bell's inability to see a world beyond the context of military and economic Big Stuff is what dates this book most of all.
